question:
Sisodiya Rajput ruler of Mewar, Amar Singh accepted Mughal services during the reign of ___________.

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Amar Singh, the Sisodiya Rajput ruler of Mewar, accepted Mughal service during the reign of Emperor Jahangir.
  • After prolonged resistance by Mewar against Mughal dominance, Amar Singh signed a treaty of submission with Jahangir in 1615.
  • This treaty allowed Amar Singh to retain his territory and titles while acknowledging Mughal suzerainty.
  • The agreement marked the end of Mewar’s long-standing conflict with the Mughals that began during Akbar’s reign.
  • Amar Singh’s acceptance of Mughal service helped bring political stability to the region and integrated Mewar into the Mughal administrative framework.
  • This also reflected Jahangir’s policy of conciliation and diplomacy towards Rajput rulers.

question:
Who among the following succeeded the throne of the Mughal Dynasty in India after Akbar?

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• After the death of Emperor Akbar in 1605, the Mughal throne was succeeded by his son, Jahangir (birth name: Nur-ud-din Muhammad Salim).
  • Jahangir continued to consolidate the empire and is known for his patronage of the arts, justice, and administration.
  • His reign lasted from 1605 to 1627, during which the Mughal Empire remained stable and prosperous.
  • Jahangir also maintained diplomatic relations with European powers such as the British and Portuguese.
  • His succession marked the continuation of the Akbar’s legacy and set the stage for the reign of his son, Shah Jahan.
  • Jahangir’s period saw further cultural and architectural advancements in the Mughal court.

question:
Who among the following wrote the biography of Jahangir known as Iqbalnama-i Jahangiri?

SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The biography of Jahangir, known as Iqbalnama-i Jahangiri, was written by Mutamid Khan.
  • Mutamid Khan was a court historian during Jahangir’s reign and documented the emperor’s life and achievements.
  • The work provides valuable insights into Jahangir’s personality, governance, and the events of his time.
  • It complements other historical texts like Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri (Jahangir’s own autobiography).
  • Mutamid Khan’s biography is an important source for studying the Mughal period during Jahangir’s rule.
  • His writings reflect the cultural and political atmosphere of the early 17th century Mughal court.

question:
Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri' was originally written in which of the following languages?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri, also known as Jahangirnama, is the autobiography of Mughal Emperor Jahangir.
  • It was originally written in Persian, which was the official language of the Mughal court and administration.
  • The work provides a detailed account of Jahangir’s life, reign, personal reflections, and the political and cultural conditions of his time.
  • It is considered one of the most important sources for understanding the Mughal period during Jahangir’s rule.
  • Persian was widely used by the Mughal emperors and nobles for literary and official purposes.
  • The Tuzuk reflects Jahangir’s keen interest in nature, art, and governance.

question:
Sarai Nurmahal is a centrally protected monument of India. It is situated in which state of India?

SSC MTS 08/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Sarai Nurmahal is located in the Jalandhar district of Punjab.
  • It is a centrally protected monument under the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI).
  • The sarai was constructed during the Mughal period, specifically under the rule of Emperor Jahangir, for his wife Nur Jahan, after whom it is named.
  • It served as a rest house (sarai) for travellers and royal caravans moving between Delhi and Lahore.
  • The architecture of Sarai Nurmahal showcases typical Mughal features like arched gateways, ornamental carvings, and a central courtyard.

question:
Mehrunnisa married Emperor Jahangir in ____________.

SSC MTS 26/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Mehrunnisa, later known as Nur Jahan, married Emperor Jahangir in 1611.
  • After her marriage, she became the 20th wife of Jahangir and quickly rose to a position of exceptional power and prestige in the Mughal court.
  • She was granted the title 'Nur Jahan', meaning 'Light of the World', by Jahangir.
  • Her political wisdom, administrative skills, and active involvement in governance made her the only Mughal empress to wield actual power.
  • She also issued imperial orders (farmans), minted coins in her name, and influenced court appointments and state policies.

Additional Information:

  • Nur Jahan was born in 1577 in Kandahar (present-day Afghanistan) to a Persian noble family.
  • Before marrying Jahangir, she was married to Sher Afghan, a Mughal officer. After his death, she lived as a widow for a few years before her marriage to Jahangir.
  • She was known for her patronage of art, architecture, and trade, and played a key role in promoting Mughal fashion and culture.
  • Structures like Sarai Nurmahal and her own tomb in Lahore are examples of her architectural contributions.

question:
The tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah, inlaid with Pietra dura decoration, is located at:

SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• The Tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah is located in Agra, Uttar Pradesh.
  • It was commissioned by Nur Jahan for her father Mirza Ghiyas Beg, who was given the title Itimad-ud-Daulah (meaning “Pillar of the State”).
  • This tomb is often referred to as the “Baby Taj” because it was a forerunner and inspiration for the Taj Mahal.
  • The structure is particularly famous for its intricate Pietra Dura (stone inlay) work, which involves embedding semi-precious stones into marble.
  • It is also the first Mughal tomb to be made entirely of white marble, marking a shift from the earlier use of red sandstone.

Additional Information:

  • The tomb was built between 1622 and 1628.
  • It stands on the eastern bank of the Yamuna River.
  • The design reflects strong Persian architectural influence, with a square structure, corner minarets, and delicate lattice screens (jali work).
  • This monument also represents the transition in Mughal architecture from the earlier Akbari style to the more refined and symmetrical Shahjahani style.

question: Jahangir ascended the Mughal throne in:
solution:
• Jahangir, whose real name was Nur-ud-din Muhammad Salim, ascended the Mughal throne in 1605 after the death of his father, Emperor Akbar.
  • Akbar passed away on 27 October 1605, and Salim took the title Jahangir, which means "Conqueror of the World".
  • His reign marked a period of relative political stability, cultural flourishing, and increasing influence of royal women, particularly his wife Nur Jahan.
  • Jahangir is also known for establishing a golden chain of justice outside his palace to allow citizens to directly petition the emperor.

Additional Information:

  • Jahangir ruled from 1605 to 1627.
  • His reign is known for extensive painting patronage, detailed memoirs (Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri), and growing European contact through Jesuit missionaries and traders.
  • He had to suppress several rebellions early in his reign, including that of his own son Khusrau, who was defeated and blinded.
  • The famous fifth Sikh Guru, Guru Arjan Dev, was executed during his rule, further straining relations between the Mughals and the Sikhs.

question: Jahangir was the son of which Mughal emperor?
solution:
• Jahangir was the son of Emperor Akbar, the third ruler of the Mughal dynasty.
  • Akbar had three sons, but it was his eldest surviving son Salim (later known as Jahangir) who succeeded him.
  • Jahangir’s mother was Empress Mariam-uz-Zamani, a Rajput princess and the daughter of Raja Bharmal of Amber (Jaipur).
  • Jahangir was born in 1569 and ascended the throne in 1605, taking the title Nur-ud-din Muhammad Jahangir.

Additional Information:

  • Akbar gave Jahangir experience in administration by making him governor of several provinces during his youth.
  • However, tensions existed between father and son, and at one point, Salim rebelled against Akbar but was later forgiven.
  • Jahangir continued many of Akbar's policies, especially in terms of art, architecture, religious tolerance, and administration.
  • His reign saw the continuation of Mughal prosperity and cultural refinement established by Akbar.

question: What was Jahangir’s real name?
solution:
• Jahangir’s real name was Salim.
  • He was born in 1569 to Emperor Akbar and Empress Mariam-uz-Zamani.
  • His name was inspired by Salim Chishti, a Sufi saint whose blessings were believed to have led to Salim’s birth.
  • When he ascended the throne in 1605, he adopted the title Nur-ud-din Muhammad Jahangir, which means “Conqueror of the World”.
  • He ruled the Mughal Empire from 1605 to 1627.

Additional Information:

  • Khurram (option a) was the real name of Shah Jahan, Jahangir's son.
  • Daniyal (option c) was Jahangir’s younger brother.
  • Akram (option d) has no historical association with Jahangir.
  • Jahangir is well known for his patronage of arts, justice system, and his close relationship with Empress Nur Jahan.

question: Jahangir’s wife, who played an active role in administration, was:
solution:
• Nur Jahan was the wife of Emperor Jahangir and played a highly influential role in the administration of the Mughal Empire.
  • Her real name was Mehrunnisa, and she married Jahangir in 1611.
  • She was granted the title "Nur Jahan", meaning "Light of the World".
  • She effectively ruled the empire behind the scenes, issuing royal decrees (farmans), minting coins in her name, and having a strong influence on court politics, trade, and military decisions.
  • Jahangir was often ill and addicted to opium and alcohol, which allowed Nur Jahan to assume real administrative power.

Additional Information:

  • Nur Jahan came from a Persian noble family and was previously married to Sher Afghan, a Mughal officer.
  • She was the only Mughal empress to have coins issued in her name, a rare honour for a woman in the Mughal era.
  • She also took active interest in art, architecture, and the construction of buildings like Sarai Nurmahal and her father's tomb Itimad-ud-Daulah in Agra.
  • Other options:
    • Gulbadan Begum: Akbar's aunt and author of Humayun Nama.
    • Ruqaiya Sultan Begum: Akbar’s chief wife.
    • Hamida Banu Begum: Mother of Akbar and wife of Humayun.

question: Nur Jahan’s father, who became an influential noble in Jahangir’s court, was:
solution:
• Nur Jahan’s father was Mirza Ghiyas Beg, a Persian noble who rose to prominence in the Mughal court.
  • He was given the title Itimad-ud-Daulah, meaning “Pillar of the State”, by Emperor Jahangir after Nur Jahan’s marriage to him in 1611.
  • As Itimad-ud-Daulah, he became an influential noble, holding high offices and playing a crucial advisory role in state affairs.
  • His tomb, commissioned by Nur Jahan, is located in Agra and is a major example of early Mughal marble architecture with intricate Pietra Dura inlay.

Additional Information:

  • Mirza Ghiyas Beg migrated from Persia to India and initially served under Emperor Akbar.
  • His family became one of the most powerful during Jahangir’s reign — with his daughter Nur Jahan as Empress and his son Asaf Khan as a high-ranking general and father of Mumtaz Mahal (wife of Shah Jahan).
  • The tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah is often called the "Baby Taj" and is considered a precursor to the Taj Mahal.

question: Jahangir issued which famous decree promising justice to all?
solution:
• Jahangir issued the famous "Chain of Justice" (also known as Zanjir-i-Adl) decree soon after ascending the throne in 1605.
  • This decree was symbolic of Jahangir’s commitment to provide impartial and accessible justice to all his subjects, irrespective of their social or economic status.
  • A golden chain with 60 bells was hung between the Agra Fort and the river Yamuna, and anyone seeking justice could pull the chain to directly appeal to the emperor.
  • Jahangir himself mentioned this in his memoirs Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri, reflecting his ambition to be a just ruler.

Additional Information:

  • The idea behind the Chain of Justice was inspired by earlier Islamic traditions and possibly some Persian influences, but its scale and visibility under Jahangir were unique.
  • Jahangir was deeply influenced by his father Akbar’s emphasis on justice, and the chain was a public symbol of accountability.
  • Other options:
    • Sulh-i-Kul Farman: Associated with Akbar’s policy of universal tolerance.
    • Mahzarnama: Declaration issued by Akbar asserting his authority in religious matters over ulema.
    • Mansabdari Order: A ranking system for administration and military under the Mughals, introduced by Akbar.

question: The Chain of Justice was installed by Jahangir at:
solution:
• The Chain of Justice (Zanjir-i-Adl) was installed by Emperor Jahangir at Agra, outside his royal palace.
  • It was a golden chain with 60 bells, meant to provide direct access to justice for any common citizen.
  • If anyone had a grievance or was denied justice by local officials, they could pull the chain to draw the emperor’s attention.
  • Jahangir implemented this system to ensure transparency and accountability in governance and to portray himself as a protector of justice.
  • This incident is documented in Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri, his official autobiography.

Additional Information:

  • Jahangir was deeply inspired by Persian ideals of kingship, where a ruler was expected to be accessible and just.
  • The idea of such a chain symbolised a ruler’s direct connection with the people, bypassing the corrupt bureaucracy.
  • Mughal architecture and governance during Jahangir’s reign reflect a blend of justice, art, and public welfare.

question: Which region was annexed by Jahangir after defeating Rana Amar Singh?
solution:
• The correct answer is Mewar.
  • Jahangir successfully brought Mewar under Mughal control after defeating Rana Amar Singh, the son of Maharana Pratap.
  • The prolonged conflict between the Mughals and Mewar had begun under Akbar and continued during Jahangir’s reign.
  • In 1615, Rana Amar Singh accepted Mughal suzerainty and signed a peace treaty with Jahangir.
  • Unlike earlier harsh terms, Jahangir offered lenient conditions, allowing the Rana to retain control over his territory and not appear personally in the Mughal court.
  • This event marked the end of nearly four decades of resistance by Mewar against Mughal rule.

Additional Information:

  • Mewar was the last major Rajput kingdom to accept Mughal overlordship.
  • Jahangir sent his son Prince Khurram (later Shah Jahan) to lead the campaign against Amar Singh.
  • After the treaty, the Mughal-Rajput relationship stabilised, and many Rajputs entered imperial service.
  • Malwa, Berar, and Khandesh were already annexed by Akbar before Jahangir’s reign.

question: Which Sikh Guru was executed during Jahangir’s reign?
solution:
• The Sikh Guru who was executed during Jahangir’s reign was Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru of the Sikhs.
  • He was arrested in 1606 and executed in Lahore on the orders of Emperor Jahangir.
  • The main reason for his execution was his support for Jahangir’s rebellious son, Prince Khusrau, who was fleeing from his father and had received blessings from Guru Arjan.
  • Jahangir viewed this act as political defiance and also suspected Guru Arjan of promoting a new religious ideology that could challenge Mughal authority.
  • Guru Arjan Dev’s death marked a turning point in Sikh history, initiating a shift from spiritual guidance to military resistance, which was later led by Guru Hargobind, his son.

Additional Information:

  • Guru Arjan Dev compiled the Adi Granth, the primary scripture of Sikhism, and laid the foundation of the Golden Temple (Harmandir Sahib) in Amritsar.
  • His execution is considered the first martyrdom in Sikh history.
  • This incident deeply influenced the community's evolution, preparing the Sikhs for future conflicts with the Mughals.
  • Other options:
    • Guru Ram Das was the 4th Sikh Guru and founder of Amritsar.
    • Guru Tegh Bahadur, the 9th Guru, was executed later during Aurangzeb’s reign.
    • Guru Nanak was the founder and first Guru of Sikhism.

question: Jahangir is known for his patronage of which art form?
solution:
• Jahangir is especially known for his patronage of Mughal miniature painting.
  • He had a deep interest in art, nature, and portraiture, and his court saw the golden age of Mughal painting.
  • Under his reign, the Mughal school of art became more refined, with greater attention to realism, facial expressions, and natural details like plants, birds, and animals.
  • Jahangir encouraged individual portraits, naturalistic depictions, and even commissioned paintings of foreign envoys and rare animals.
  • Famous painters in his court included Ustad Mansur, Abul Hasan, and Bichitr.

Additional Information:

  • Jahangir’s autobiography Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri contains several references to his love for art and painting.
  • He was influenced by European techniques, especially in shading and perspective, brought in by Jesuit missionaries.
  • Unlike Akbar’s focus on narrative illustrations, Jahangir promoted single-subject portraits and detailed nature studies.
  • Other options:
    • Temple architecture was not promoted by Jahangir, as it is primarily associated with Hindu rulers.
    • Persian music was respected but not Jahangir's main focus.
    • Rajput dance was a regional tradition, not an imperial patronage under Jahangir.

question: The Mughal painting style under Jahangir emphasized:
solution:
• The Mughal painting style under Jahangir saw significant development, especially in terms of realism and natural observation.
  • Jahangir had a keen interest in portraiture and was deeply fascinated by the natural world, including birds, animals, and plants.
  • He encouraged artists to paint detailed, lifelike portraits of court members and to closely observe and depict nature and wildlife with scientific accuracy.
  • Many paintings from his era focus on naturalistic representation, making it a hallmark of his reign.

question: Which English ambassador came to Jahangir’s court to seek trade privileges?
solution:
• The English ambassador who came to the court of Mughal Emperor Jahangir to seek trade privileges was Sir Thomas Roe.
  • He was sent by King James I of England in 1615 as an official ambassador of the East India Company.
  • Sir Thomas Roe stayed at Jahangir’s court from 1615 to 1619 and held several diplomatic meetings with the emperor.
  • His primary aim was to obtain firmans (royal permits) that would allow the English to establish factories (trading posts) in India.
  • Although he did not secure immediate large-scale privileges, his mission laid the foundation for future British trade expansion in India.

question: Jahangir gave trade concessions to which European company in 1615?
option_3: English East India Company
option_4: French East India Company
solution:
• In 1615, Emperor Jahangir granted trade concessions to the English East India Company.
  • These concessions were given after the diplomatic mission of Sir Thomas Roe, who was sent by King James I of England.
  • Jahangir issued firmans (royal orders) allowing the English to establish factories (trading posts) in India, starting with Surat.
  • This event marked a significant moment in Indian history, as it laid the foundation for long-term British commercial and political presence in India.

question: Who among the following was the commander of Jahangir’s expedition to Deccan?
solution:
• The commander of Jahangir’s expedition to the Deccan was Prince Khurram, who later became the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan.
  • Around 1617, Jahangir sent Prince Khurram to lead a major campaign against the Ahmadnagar Sultanate in the Deccan region.
  • Prince Khurram achieved considerable success in this expedition, securing Jahangir's authority in parts of the Deccan.
  • As a reward for his success, Jahangir bestowed upon him the title "Shah Jahan", meaning "King of the World".

question: The tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah at Agra is significant because it:
option_1: Was the first Mughal tomb made entirely of marble
option_2: Was built by Shah Jahan
option_3: Used red sandstone extensively
solution:
• The tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah at Agra is significant because it was the first Mughal tomb built entirely of white marble, marking a major shift in Mughal architectural style.
  • It was commissioned by Nur Jahan, the wife of Jahangir, in memory of her father Mirza Ghiyas Beg, who held the title Itimad-ud-Daulah.
  • Constructed between 1622 and 1628, this tomb is often referred to as the "jewel box" or "Baby Taj" because of its intricate inlay work and delicate design.
  • Its style laid the groundwork for future marble structures like the Taj Mahal, showcasing the transition from red sandstone to white marble in Mughal architecture.

question: The autobiography of Jahangir is known as:
solution:
• The autobiography of Jahangir is known as Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri or Jahangirnama.
  • It was written in Persian, the official language of the Mughal court.
  • The book provides a detailed account of Jahangir's administration, justice system, and personal life.
  • He personally wrote entries from 1605 (his accession) to 1622.
  • After 1622, the remaining parts were completed by court historians like Mu‘tamad Khan.

question: Jahangir’s rebellion against Akbar in his youth was due to:
solution:
• Jahangir (Prince Salim) rebelled against his father Akbar in the later years of Akbar’s reign.
  • The main reason was a conflict over succession, as Jahangir was impatient to become emperor.
  • Around 1599, while Akbar was campaigning in the Deccan, Jahangir declared himself emperor in Allahabad.
  • This created significant tension between father and son, though Akbar did not remove Jahangir from succession.
  • Eventually, the conflict was resolved, and Jahangir was accepted as heir; he ascended the throne peacefully after Akbar’s death in 1605.

question: Nur Jahan formed a power group known as:
solution:
• Nur Jahan, wife of Emperor Jahangir, played a dominant role in Mughal court politics.
  • She formed a powerful faction at court known as the Nur Jahan Junta.
  • This group included her father Itimad-ud-Daulah (Mirza Ghiyas Beg), her brother Asaf Khan, and her son-in-law Prince Khurram (later Shah Jahan) (initially).
  • Through this group, Nur Jahan exercised significant influence over imperial appointments and decisions.
  • Her control over administration was so strong that coins were even minted in her name during Jahangir’s reign.

question: Which Mughal prince revolted against Jahangir and later became emperor?
solution:
• The Mughal prince who revolted against Jahangir and later became emperor was Prince Khurram, who took the title Shah Jahan.
  • Around 1622, Khurram rebelled due to increasing influence of Nur Jahan at court, fearing she would sideline him in favour of another successor.
  • He gathered support and even fought imperial forces but was eventually defeated and forced to surrender.
  • Despite the rebellion, he was later forgiven and, after Jahangir’s death in 1627, he ascended the throne in 1628.
  • As emperor, Shah Jahan is known for monumental architecture, including the Taj Mahal.

question: Jahangir’s court included which famous painter known for flora and fauna illustrations?
solution:
• The famous painter at Jahangir’s court known for his exceptional illustrations of flora and fauna was Ustad Mansur.
  • He specialised in naturalistic paintings of birds, animals, and plants, reflecting Jahangir’s deep interest in nature and zoology.
  • Ustad Mansur's most famous works include illustrations of the dodo, Siberian crane, and various exotic animals.
  • His precise and scientific style made him one of the leading painters of Jahangir’s atelier.
  • Jahangir praised Mansur’s work highly in his autobiography, Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri.

question: Jahangir’s reign is seen as a period of:
option_3: Artistic refinement and stability
solution:
• Jahangir’s reign (1605–1627) is considered a period of artistic refinement and relative stability in the Mughal Empire.
  • He was deeply interested in painting, architecture, and natural sciences, and actively promoted court art and literature.
  • Under his rule, Mughal painting reached new heights, especially in portraiture and nature-based illustrations.
  • The empire remained mostly politically stable, with only limited military campaigns, such as in the Deccan and against rebellious nobles.
  • Jahangir’s court also saw intellectual and diplomatic exchanges, including the visit of Sir Thomas Roe from England.

question: Which architectural style started to influence Mughal buildings under Jahangir?
option_4: Rajput and Persian fusion
solution:
• During Jahangir’s reign, Mughal architecture began to show a distinct fusion of Persian and Rajput styles.
  • While Persian influence had been present earlier, Jahangir's period saw greater incorporation of Rajput elements such as chhatris (domed pavilions), jharokhas (overhanging balconies), and intricate carvings.
  • This fusion reflected the growing political and matrimonial alliances with Rajput rulers.
  • Structures like the tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah in Agra are prime examples of this blended architectural style.
  • The blend of symmetry, decorative motifs, and regional aesthetics became a hallmark of later Mughal architecture, culminating under Shah Jahan.

question: The famous Mughal garden "Shalimar Bagh" in Kashmir was developed during the reign of:
solution:
• The famous Shalimar Bagh in Kashmir was developed during the reign of Emperor Jahangir.
  • Jahangir had a deep love for nature and gardens, especially the serene landscapes of Kashmir.
  • Shalimar Bagh was laid out in 1619 by Jahangir for his wife Nur Jahan, showcasing Persian-style charbagh (four-part) layout.
  • It is one of the finest examples of Mughal garden architecture, blending symmetry, water channels, and natural beauty.
  • Jahangir’s affection for Kashmir is well documented in his autobiography, Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri.
